titleInfo.title: 'File No. G/7 II Id Calls & Letters'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file. The file notes of this file can be found at the end of file IOR/R/15/2/1944 ‘File G/7 III Id Calls. Correspondence with the Shaikhs of the T. Coast.’, (folios 374-383). These are dated 1940-1943.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 307; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 3-306; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence in the form of letters sent between the Political Agency, Bahrain, and various Gulf rulers and shaikhs mainly on the occasions of ‘Eid al-Fitr and ‘Eid al-Adha between 1940 and 1943. A memorandum was sent by the Agency to the Naval Officer in charge that the Agency Flagstaff would be dressed on the occasions of the first day of each ‘Eid.‘Eid greetings were sent by the appointed Political Agent in Bahrain, including Hugh Weightman and Reginald Alban, and on behalf of the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Charles Prior, to Gulf rulers and shaikhs including the Ruler of Bahrain (Hamad bin ‘Isa Al-Khalifah), the Ruler of Qatar (Shaikh Abdullah bin Jasim Al-Thani), and the Ruler of Dubai (Said bin Maktum). The Political Agent paid visits to the shaikhs of the ruling family in Bahrain as well as to the notables of Manama and Muharraq, such as Muhammad Tayeb Khunji and Yusuf bin Adulrahman Fakhroo, during the ‘Eid festivals. The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf joined the Political Agent on those visits when he was in Bahrain.The Gulf rulers and shaikhs wrote back to the Political Agent thanking him for his ‘Eid greetings. ‘Eid greetings were also sent between the Residency Agent on the Trucial Coast and the Political Agent in Bahrain. Most of the correspondence is in Arabic.
